item.dc:creator: @nickog15 nickog15
item.description:
@nickog15 wrote:

If it makes them happy…
France -

PARIS (AP) — The French Senate has voted to legalize same-sex marriage in France, putting a landmark bill on track to become law by summer.

The vote in the upper house of parliament — led by President Francois Hollande’s Socialists — comes despite boisterous protests. Opponents — mostly conservatives and fervent Roman Catholics — have sought to defend traditional marriage.

Both houses of parliament will now take up a second reading to consider minor Senate changes to the bill passed in February by the National Assembly, also controlled by a Socialist-led majority.

The bill would allow gay marriage and let same-sex couples adopt children. On the campaign trail last year, Hollande pledged to push through such legislation if elected.

About a dozen mostly European nations already allow gay marriage.

item.title: Gay Marriage
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

This post may be rather convoluted, I’m trying to convey several ideas from several standpoints to multiple people and posts in this thread with multiple arguments, and that never ends good.

Davidi2:

I think that forcing Christians to accept gays into their marriage definition is wrong. It would be like trying to convince Jews to change their bar mitzvah tradition. I say this because of how marriage is done right now – with the Christian bible and ‘in the name of God’.

I’d rather not do this but I feel it needs to be done Davidi2, marriage is NOT a religious act nor is it a Christian one. The mere fact that you perceive marriage as a Christian ‘owned’ ceremony is more to do with the fact that Christianity is the dominant religion in your country, you know, you weren’t exactly claiming that marriage is an Islamic ceremony or that we should uphold Islamic ideas of marriage now were you? To further my point, marriage is first and foremost a legal term that offers legal rights, Christian churches do not define what legal rights marriage offers nor do they control who gets to marry, those are defined in the legal definition of marriage. The whole idea that we should respect a churches idea of who should be marriage is also bunk, I completely agree with Bowser, if a church wants to obtain a licence to grant the legal contract of being married then they should damn well grant the contract of marriage to anyone that legally qualifies, it is NOT the churches decision to decide who can and who cannot get married. HOWEVER, if a church wants to refuse the religious ceremony part of a marriage in their church, then that’s their prerogative, however distasteful and discriminatory it may be.

To further expand on why I think allowing churches to decide who cannot get married to be bunk: the analogy of a radical lesbian Feminism church was brought up, how about an Islamic church in America refusing to marry people who aren’t Muslims? What about a church of paedophilia who refused to marry a couple unless a member of the couple was a child? They sure as hell won’t be marrying anyone, but should they be allowed to receive a licence to allow them to marry people? They aren’t breaking any rules, on what basis will you refuse issuing the licence?

But I completely agree with you Davidi2 in the sense that marriage should not be de facto standard, civil unions are what they should be called and marriage should merely be an optional additional part of a civil union, marriage in the eyes of god and civil unions in the eyes of the law and all that good stuff.

Davidi2:

I think if a religion discriminates, you shouldn’t force them to change their religion to force your views on them. It’s setting a double standard if you get angry when religious people try to put their views into government and then you get surprised if they get upset when you try to force your views of what marriage is onto them. Like I pointed out in my previous post, marriage is held out here with their Bible and in the name of THEIR God

Again I view this whole idea as complete bunk. Which Christian sect are we pandering to? Because many Christian sects recognise same-sex marriages, further more what about other religions? Should we pander to some sects of Islam which state we should allow men to have multiple wives? I know this is a bit of a strawman, but I’m making it to get my point across. If a church is being granted a licence to allow two individuals to enter a legally binding contract, they should not be at liberty to decide who can and cannot enter that contract, regardless if other means are available. The licence is given to allow people to get married, not to allow churches to uphold their bigotry. If a church doesn’t want to marry same-sex couples then they don’t get the licence, it changes nothing for the church, people can still have their religious ceremony there and the church can refuse to allow same-sex couples to have a religious ceremony, the only difference is that the church is no longer at liberty to be discriminatory in their decision to grant a legal god damn right.

But again, I completely agree that marriage shouldn’t be the legal term, but that’s a discussion for another topic.

[quote=“amy_webb, post:46, topic:515039”]I agree with David, except the reason homosexual couples are fighting for religious marriage is because they still follow that religion. They wish to be acknowledged by their religion, rather then have them be forced to marry them.

Creating a different ceremony in order to show that the two have been united just separates equal rights for them, so it wouldn’t solve the problem. As it is, homosexual couples can already have a ceremony where they’re joined as partners (which is recognised by law). That still isn’t enough for them, they want to be treated fairly.[/quote]

The general discussion is about America as can probably be clued from being even the slightest bit aware of American politics. Civil unions in America are NOT equivalent to marriage, as it stands, marriage is de facto standard for legal rights between couples. But I’m glad that you recognise that limiting same-sex couples, by law, into civil unions is at least discriminatory. I won’t bother going into a wall of text to explain why.

amy_webb:

People believe in something because they choose to, in today’s society. Not because they are being forced to do so by a previous generation, or because they had been forced many generations ago.

In today’s society an a ‘liberal’ enough country, that’s an important distinction. If you were born into an oppressive country you WILL believe your parents religion or you’ll be punished, that is not a choice.

amy_webb:

People do choose their religions, it is not forced upon them dispute the influences from relatives or loved ones. Once someone is old enough to think for themselves, they’re old enough to make their own decisions.

Again this is ONLY true if you are in a modern enough country if you will, the fact that you can choose what you want to believe is a relatively new phenomena. If you live in an oppressive country the choice of freedom of expression does not exist, historically people HAVE been killed for choosing a different religion.
